reviewText: I got this DVD a week ago and I have watched it non-stop. This is the REAL Kiss* (my rant about what is being passed off as Kiss in 2006-2007 is below). This is Kiss in the prime time. Before and during the time when this band took over the world. It gets no better than this I promise you!!!You have over 6 hours of vintage footage here. Every second of it is worth it's weight in gold. You get some TV clips from the mid 70's but most of this is Kiss live. This set has 4 COMPLETE LIVE SHOWS from 1975-1977!!!Winterland, San Francisco: This show is AMAZING. Not only is the sound flawless for a 32 year old concert (play this on a surround sound unit with lots of bass and get BLOWN AWAY) and it is filmed in black and white. It gives the show a unique feel. This is very early Kiss. The band already had its famous choreography down, but did not have its huge hit songs yet, or any elaborate stage or explosions. Peter's drums do lift about 10 feet off the ground at one point. Which is impressive for a band that admits it was BROKE at the time, and this was in 1975! The high point (for me) of this concert is the song "Watchin' you". I have literally watched this song 50 times. This is pure talent and anyone that says Kiss could not play should watch this one. Kiss Is awe-inspiring on this funky track. Ace is jaw-dropping. Peter is a beast. All in all the Winterland show is down right amazing. The band is so tight. Every instrument is spot on. Every member of the band is in top form. This concert is worth the price of this DVD by its self!Cobo Hall, Detroit: I may be biased because I am from this neck of the woods. But THIS is where Kiss grew leaps and bounds. Detroit is Kiss' favorite place to play and it shows here. Explosions... check. Fire... check. A+ stage show and musicianship... check. The high spot of the show for me here was "She/Watchin' you and Parasite". Ace does his famous smoking guitar. Gene does his blood puke. Peter has a drum kit that come out 10 feet and up 20. This concert has about 5 encores. The fans were off the chart.Budokan Hall, Tokyo: Kiss was huge in Japan (along with other monsters such as Gamera and Godzilla). This is another excellent show. The song "Beth" is played, as well as "Detroit Rock City" and "Rock and Roll All Night". Another amazing set.The Summit, Houston: Yet another fine set from the boysIf you do not own this DVD you are not a fan of rock music period. All 4 members are in top form here. This is all I will ever need. This is the best music DVD ever released!!!*The Kiss of 2006-2007 is not a band. It is a corporation. It is purely business. Gene Simmons is Donald Trump with a bass guitar. He owns the rights to the music and the rights to the marketing. He has basically cut Peter Criss and Ace Frehley a raw deal. These guys get next to nothing. They do not profit off of merchandise that carries there likeness. "Kiss Inc." owns the "Cat Man" and "Space Ace" characters that Peter and Ace CREATED. The modern Kiss has Ace and Peter FAKES that dress like them, wear the same make-up, act like them and play like them. And I feel sorry for the individuals that CREATED these characters. Ace and Peter WERE KISS. And it stinks for these founding members to be treated so poorly. BOYCOT the new KISS!!!!!!!

reviewText: If you're a big Kiss fan and don't already own this, there's a few things to know. Like any fan or critic or has reviewed this this information can be found on probably any of their essays as well but being a huge fan of the band I to must voice a little distress with what seems to be a lack of care on the bands part in putting this together. For years fans were waiting for this footage to be released "offically". 1994's Kiss My Ass along with a few other VHS's they had put out wet appetites for quite a while on vintage 70's Ace/Peter Kiss performances. This first in a 3 part collection attempts to give it to fans of course for a hefty price and even the obvious lure and bait of putting different bonus discs in each set so people would buy all 3 different versions of each set, which is ludricrious.Anyway, this is by far the best of the 3 as it covers the band in their prime, some of the earliest footage of them playing a small auditorium captures the track Acrobat which msot fans know was the 2nd part to the Love Theme From Kiss off their debut that was scrapped and its pretty cool, albeit the wear and tear of the footage (its 30 years old). The coolest thing on the set is the pre fame Kiss stuff, when they were doing TV appearences. Gene on the Mike Douglas Show (which the Kissing contest stuff edited out, WHICH can be found online) one mark taken away for that, and the complete 3 song performance they did on ABC's In Concert which is great. Seeing Kiss when they were still a widely unknown cult band, low budget outfits, no overblown pyro, is great, it really is the real Kiss. When the music meant the most, the band were playing great and it certianly wasn't mediocre like today's Kiss. With that said, the Cadillac Michigan appearence is there, along with the Alive! Promo clips, a great show on the Hotter Than Hell tour at Winterland in classic B&W;, and a great show in early 76, following their breakthrough from the Alive! album wraps up the bands 'early era' nicely.The success years are covered by their appearence on The Paul Lynde Halloween Special in Oct 76, although there the lipsynced Detriot Rock City and Beth and I believe there is one other short jokey host segment they did that isn't included, which sucks. The best concert here, I think though is the 1977 Budokan show, pre Love Gun. Great sound, great quality, played on a nice system its perfect. Then you get the Don Kirshner Rock Concert clip, and the Love Gun tour show, which is Houston 1977. Now, fans have owned bootlegs of most of this stuff for years, and the reasons they edited footage is really stupid and really knocks alot of resons to get this away. But if you really want this stuff its there. Commentary tracks are sort of enlightning but as usual, Gene and Paul are vague and sort of insinuating when it comes to talking about their other band members. The bonus disc isnt that great, a show from NYC on the Rock N Roll Over tour. There's alot of other cool stuff that coulda been on here, like the TV ad's for Hotter Than Hell, R&RO;, and Alive II, the Kiss radio (lol), and the SNL sketch with Steve Belushi, which was all on Kiss My Ass. But if you really want one set, this one is pretty good, and the best of the 3.

reviewText: Ah, the glory days. Before the disco pap of "I Was Made For Lovin You," the kiddie fans, and the lackluster solo LPs.  This DVD truely captures "the greatest band in the land" back when they could powerhouse rock, and unlike many other releases put out over the years, this footage actually captures whole sets in their entirety with few exceptions...Even if you are only casual Kiss fan, you MUST get this collection! It includes rare raw live footage from 74,75,76, and 77, promo clips, and even a bonus disc from Madison Square Garden.  Sure, there are a few blips (mainly in the "Winterland" show) due to the archival footage of the master tapes, but overall this is a fantastic treat for anyone familiar with their first three LPs and missing the fabulous stage show that set them apart from their boring contemporaries.  I saw them live--this is almost as fun as being at the show!  It's amazing just how much energy Paul exuded, and it's still great fun watching the comic book antics of Gene, which are unintentionally funny while also grotesque (Also included in this set is rare footage of Gene's hair catching on fire at the Cobo Hall).  Best of all, this classic footage finally puts to rest the ongoing sour grapes of those critics who asserted Ace couldn't play--Not only can he play a hell of a riff, but when you consider how high he must've been when this stuff was filmed, you'll agree his mastery of the instrument is what set the standard for later imitators...who else is gonna give ya this much bang for your buck!  Have fun, it won't dissappoint!
summary: Entertaining romp thru raw footage and rare promos

reviewText: Considering all the other reviews and some comments I've read on Internet forums, I have basically three things to say:1) Anyone judging the picture quality by today's standards is missing the point. This is archival footage, not concerts shot especially for release, where all the cameras and microphones are strategically placed, some numbers are played again because they didn't get it right the first time and additional footage is shot after the actual show. In fact, we Kiss fans should be thankful these concerts were videotaped at all! We're talking '74-'77 here. "Acrobat" looks like footage from the silent Super-8 film originally shown on the "Vintage" DVD with the audio dubbed in, but it works. The Easter Egg with Kiss playing at Ace's wedding is too dark, but it's the historical value that counts. And you can confirm that it is really from the wedding by checking the pictures that appear in the "Kiss and Tell" book.2) So most of this material has been long available on bootleg. So what? Do you really expect the musicians themselves to take this into consideration? Personally, I always prefer official material, even if it looks and sounds exactly the same as the bootlegs. Now it's all in one place on a properly pressed DVD and a nice package. For me, at least, it does make an enormous difference.3) This is a first in the music video market. Queen has given us a few concerts one at a time, but we know there is more in the vaults. Both the Rolling Stones and Elton John have released an overdose of recent footage in their respective 4-DVD sets, while the best stuff remains in the can. The Beatles have included bits and pieces in the "Anthology" series, but not complete performances. Kiss has started a new trend, here. I hope other acts follow suit: David Bowie, Genesis, Elton John, are you listening?
summary: This should set a new trend in the music video market

reviewText: KISSology Vol. 1, 1974-1977 shows just what a powerhouse of a band KISS was in the early days.  Peter Criss and Ace Frehley - who later became liabilities in the band musically - were in top form in this period.  Peter plays with reckless abandon, and Ace plays with style and flair.  This also happens to show that their earliest material (from their first 3 albums) was arguably their strongest up until Revenge in 1992.The concerts in this set are shows that have been widely bootlegged, but the bootlegs were of poor audio and video quality, and here they are shows in the best possible quality.  Sadly, a couple of the original master tapes have some deterioration (Cobo Hall, 1976 especially), but it's never all that bad, and the imperfections in the original master tape never last that long.It's interesting to see the KISS stage show deveop from the very early days until the "peak" on the Love Gun tour.  They keep adding to the stage set, and it gets bigger and bigger until you see what made the band's reputation back in 1976/1977.The TV appearances are nice bonuses, and the "easter eggs" are fantastic lost gems, too.All in all, exactly the set most KISS fans wanted.  If they can release further volumes as comprehensive as this one (hopefully no eras will be left out - they need to include the Hot In The Shade tour, and the Revenge tour as well on future releases) then KISS fans will finally have the concert collection that they've requested from the band for years.

reviewText: CRAZY..  I wanna rock n roll all night - and party every day!  This video boggles the mind brings back some seriously old memories - not necessarily of having seen Kiss as a kid, cause I never did.  But magazine shots and a glimpse or two on TV before my mom turned it off (we were 6, and totally into it!) were enough to permanently etch KISS into the collage of mental impressions that I now call "the 70s".  And while we used to pretend to be the guys in KISS in the same way we played 'Star Wars', I never went through school as a Kiss fan.  Granted, by the time we were starting to really get into music in the early 80s, Kiss was no longer a phenomenon. But they were always there, lurking in the subconscious, whether you knew their music or not!I just picked up this video then, to revisit a time in my life that would have put me in first or second grade - when these guys were doing this.  What an era we lived in!  These guys were outrageous.  This DVD gives you a pretty good time window that shows Kiss evolving in the mid-70s with talk shows or visits to high schools in between stadium shows.  They created a pretty good rapport with the audience during the shows, definitely what you could call a party band.  Their gimmick needs no explanation although it's fun to analyze KISS.  You had Gene Simmons dripping blood, spitting fire and making lewd gestures with his tongue (even when he's on the Mike Douglas Show in '74 - unbeleivable - totally un-PC but back in those days rock n rollers took themselves a little more seriously).  OK, that's the freak side of the show.  Smokin Ace Freley in his spaceman get-up is a classic 70s image, right along with charazmatic Cat-man Peter Chris.  Paul Stanley, the front man if there is one, kind of balances out Gene Simmons on the left there, and while he is an energetic head-banging 70s rock n roller, you can kinda feel that he cares about the audience.  In between inciting the kids to acheive ever new levels of inebriation, he's telling the guy in the front row to settle down "It's a party, not a road war", and "KISS loves you" -- When asked by a reporter on their British tour in '76,  "What is most important to you - the spectacle or the music?"  The answer: "The audience."Other gems:"What do you represent?""Destruction.""Destruction?""Yeah, rock n roll - good stuff. Power, energy."It's fun to see after all these years just how much energy these guys had and what a stage show they could put on.  In the dictionary under 'rock show' it says in parenthesis (see also: KISS) - kidding. But seriously, seeing these shows is witnessing a chapter in rock history like no other.  The band complimented and reflected an era that many lived though.
summary: You drive us wild, we'll drive you..

reviewText: Nitpickers can go and jump off a bridge...this is what the Kiss Army members have been waiting for, for over 20 years. The most jaded Kiss "fans" here may tell you they are not happy with the video quality, but please don't listen-they've spent too many wasted hours and money on bootleg video since 1987, to have any clear perspective. The gigs range from a legendary performace at the Winterland Ballroom, in San Francisco, from January of 1975, when Kiss was still an opening band, to full-tilt KISS-Mania shows like Cobo Hall '76 in Detroit, and The Budokan in Tokyo, Japan '77. Other random highlights include a mini documentary on Kiss' 2 day assault of Cadillac, Michigan and their High School Football Team, and Kiss on the Paul Lynde Halloween Special from 1976. There is really too much killer stuff here to go thru in this review, but as a KISS fan since 1978, I ask you to trust me on this-if you love 70's KISS, and you've been waiting for them to release vintage live, and rare footage from the vaults, you WILL love this. The picture quality of these concerts range from just decent, to Excellent, and the performances are all high energy, full throttle Kiss at their peak. It's all about the high energy vibe. If you're so stuck on "oh, this isn't perfect video quality like Led Zep's dvd" then go ahead and split hairs or whine. If you like to Rock and Roll All Nite and par-tay every day, then Kissology will satisfy.Go out to Wal-Mart and get it, that version contains an exclusive bonus disc of the band live at the Capitol Centre in Largo, MD. reviewText: I, for one, am not, by any stretch of the means, the biggest Kiss fan, but as an objective viewer and listener, I could not help but be enthralled by the early showmanship of Peter, Gene, Paul, and Ace as portrayed in this disc collection.Though one might object to the lyrics or songs of the Kiss catalogue, alone, how they portrayed themselves on stage could be an entirely different matter. There was more to the performances than just the glitter, the 7-inch heels, the fake blood, the smoke, etc. As a band, Kiss has been able to put on a great show, both vocally and instrumentally.Visual settings with the advanced, creative pyrotechnics at the time served as an iconic, Barnum and Bailey type front. However, it was the live music itself that drew millions of fans worldwide. Studio releases could not do Kiss justice; for example, the staple Rock and Roll All Nite seems, to me, most bland when compared with any of their on-stage versions.Overall, Kissology, Volume I is a great package. As for the icing on the cake, there is lead guitarist Ace Frehley's outlandish 1977 performance of Shock Me, which I deem as one of the best electric guitar demonstrations ever, along with Jimi Hendrix's Wild Thing at Monterey.So for those who want to know how Kiss ever came to be the multiplatinum-selling artists we know of today, this is a perfect source to start with.
summary: GIVING CREDIT WHERE CREDIT IS DUE

reviewText: ...they come out with something better.  KISSOLOGY is the latest and greatest collection to date.  Metaldiva is a diehard fan and love, love, loves this new offering.  This is like stepping back into time for me because one of the first KISS concerts I ever saw at COBO Arena, Detroit, MI is captured live..even the skirmish in the audience that Paul squashed from onstage is there. What is even cooler, is I can tell my metalbabies that mama was there when this was taped!!When buying a DVD with extra features, the commentary can be overwhelming, here it is not.. There is just enough input from Paul and Gene's tidbits, to make the avid fan like me smile and nod and say "Wow, I didn't know that!"  The stories they tell are fascinating and fun and add to this DVD rather than detract.The footage varies concert to concert, sometimes professionally taped and others like a fan used a handheld, and yet both are thoroughly enjoyable. The behind the scene interviews as well as the early television interviews and appearances are a welcome addition to the collection. As each year progresses, the band gets better and better and by 1977 they are true artists, confidently giving fans shows of a lifetime...This is the history of the band in the truest sense of the word, all the glory and the grandeur of these masters of rock entertainment. KISS has always put us fans first and in 30+ years, they have never failed to give a great show. My first concert in 1976 in Detroit was equally good as the 2000 in Sacramento, only difference was there were more great songs to enjoy. There is nothing and no one like this in rock today and it is wonderful to have all the footage saved for future rock afficionados.Metaldiva Sez: This is definitely an ABSOLUTE MUST HAVE ADDITION FOR KISS FANS. This captures the creation and establishment of this phenomenon of rock.  It documents their early concerts and appearances with an optional commentary that is outstanding and informative without overbearing the performances.There will undoubtedly be thousands more KISS items to buy in the future, but THERE WILL NEVER EVER BE ANOTHER BAND LIKE KISS. Buy two, one to watch and one to save and take them home and get ready for a hours and hours of great music and classic performances.  I can't wait for the other two volumes to be released!!!

reviewText: Since the late 1970's, when Kiss peaked and lost their musical direction, Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley have had three trump cards that they could use to return many of their fans.  When Kiss bottomed out in the early 1980's, shortly after Peter Criss and Ace Frehley left the band, they played their first trump card, taking off their makeup and costumes.  Kiss then jumped on the Hair Metal bandwagon and road it for all that it was worth.  When the Hair Metal fad finally dried up in the 1990's Gene and Paul played their second trump card, getting back together with Peter and Ace and putting their makeup and costumes back on.  Now that Peter and Ace have left the band again and the never ending Kiss Farewell Tour with a mock cat drummer and a mock space guitarist have alienated many fans, Gene and Paul are playing their third trump card.  They have opened the Kiss vault to release full concerts and television footage of KISS back in the 1970's.  This is indeed the ultimate trump card, allowing fans to watch from the comfort of their own homes five KISS concerts (the fifth one on a bonus DVD) of the original lineup back in the 1970's.  This is KISS back when they were hungry and raising the bar for rock concerts.  The price of this DVD set is reasonable too.  Twenty bucks for what they could have easily charged fifty to a hundred bucks.  I sincerely hope that the majority Kiss fans, including casual Kiss fans, won't be so disillusioned by the last six years of Kiss that they miss out on this DVD set.  Trump card or not, this is a true treasure for any Kiss fan!  This is KISS at their best!!
summary: Kiss Plays Third Trump Card by Releasing This DVD Treasure

It has Peter Criss singing "Beth" and Paul Stanley was very high in energy.The other moments are also great.  I feel that the first disc represents KISS when they were just developing into this band.  That disc was the early years.  It shows a couple of concerts that were very similar, but they have different aspects.  It also has a live performance from their Alive tour, where they performed the album all the way through.  I guess that's the way to do things when you're doing a tour of a live album.  What else can you do in that situation?The second disc showed them during the height of their career, but when watching some of these moments with the commentary from Paul and Gene, I learn things that make me not like things as much.  However, the shows here are some of the best.  The film quality is also pretty good.  Again, the highlighting point is definitely the concert in Houston, but the rest of the set is also pretty good.The second KISSology boxed set continues from where this one leaves off.

reviewText: I'm not the biggest KISS fan, but I do love collecting pop and rock DVD's of the artists of my youth.  I don't own any KISS CD's (except for their Millennium Collection), but I would have loved to see them live back when I was a kid.  As I started building my Rock DVD Repertoire, I was hoping there would be something filmed of KISS back in the seventies.  And so, here it is.It doesn't do any good to complain about the less-than-stellar video quality of these KISS concerts and interview footage.  This footage is mastered the best they possibly could.  I truly do believe this.  We didn't have High Definition cameras back then, but we do have the technology to moderately improve on aged film filed away deep in the storage vaults.  I'm pretty pleased with this.Unless, visitors from space came to earth to film KISS performing live (with their unearthly advanced technology), this is the best we're gonna get.  Maybe, someday, some space alien will bring us some of their film footage of KISS that their space traveling ancestors captured while secretly visiting us.  We'll see.  My brother-in-law has this old 8-track tape that some space alien gave to him as an apology for landing on his roof and tearing up his antenna, back in the early eighties, back in Detroit.  He knew they couldn't pay for roof repair and other various damages, but they did give him an 8-track tape that their elder ancestors gave them of Franz Liszt performing in Europe about a century or so before.  It's only playable on an old 8-tape tape player that we have to somehow jerry-rig to this old black and white TV.  This tape only works on TV's made before 1958.  Even though this old RCA TV is black and white, the Franz Liszt performance still comes through in color.  When we watch this tape, all the clocks in the house start moving backwards and the refrigerator power diminishes.  Plus, we learned that if we have more than three gallons of milk in the fridge, one usually explodes, which makes all the eggs float upward and just stick to the top surface.  But anyway...KISS is definitely something more enjoyable as a visual experience.  Musically, there is nothing too outstanding here.  I personally like Alice Cooper (musically) more than KISS, but KISS has a more demonic presence on stage.  Alice Cooper is rather comical and campy.I'm surprised that there isn't any kind of rock group out there today that hasn't tried to simulate the KISS concept.  Masks and make-up, and a great theatrical stage show, couldn't help but be an attraction to today's concert goers.  I would imagine with CD sales dropping, the best thing a rock group could do to sell itself to the buying public, is to create a great fantasy stage show.  You can't download "being at a live show".  Performing on stage is where the money's gotta be for today's rock artist.Anyway,  if you are even just a curious KISS fan, you won't be disappointed with this DVD.  Buy it now!
summary: This is as good as it gets

reviewText: I have never been a huge KISS fan from the get go, but I've learned to respect them for what they've done and who they are. I was into bands like the Zeppelin, The Who, Pink Floyd, Judas Priest, Iron Maiden etc and Kiss never really did anything for me back then. However looking back, I probably never really gave them a chance. As time passed I began to revisit their older stuff and to my surprise, I really liked what I heard coming from my speakers. The 80's and 90's had some high points, but it's the early years that really paint the true picture of what these guys were about and I personally found this out some 20 years later. I guess you could say the their first full reunion tour was a coming out party for me *lol*.Sure Gene and Paul are businessmen and yes they looked at this as both being a way to get rich and a way to express themselves both musically and lyrically. From the moment they started out, they had a plan and followed it with the a passion. No one should ever say anything bad about that as they had a dream and they've lived that dream. They were at one time basically laughed at, however they had a vision and they worked at their craft and took on the world and it's would be critics. KISS is or was one of the worlds biggest bands and most recognizable names. They had achieved what they sought out to do and I see nothing wrong with that. They worked their butts off to show the world and probably themselves just what they could do or become. They delivered live shows that absolutely blew their audience away and their reputation and following, insert KISS ARMY here, was built on that. Make no mistake here, KISS was never the most talented band in the world, nor the best selling act ever, however they were not as untalented or as crappy as some people would have you believe. The musicianship is pretty darn good all around here so they get props from me.KISS are what they are and they are masters at what they do. They deliver great live shows time after time and they have a very good collection of albums that contain some really good tunes that have stood the test of time. They are business men who in the end have given us a good days work for many years!This DVD contains what really is KISS at it's zenith. The first disc shows us just how raw they really were when they started out. It has lots of bad notes and really funny imagery that is somewhat hilarious at times. As the disc gets further in, you can see that they are indeed getting better and are really starting to define who they are and what they could be. The second disc is really KISS at it's best!! They had found their way and were working it for all it was worth. All in all great stuff for any KISS  fan or even the casual fan like myself who over time has grown to respect what these guys were all about!Easily a 5 star rating here!!
summary: Not A Huge Kiss Fan, but!

reviewText: In the 70s Kiss was it. It was cool to be into Kiss. In the 80s, it was the exact opposite. By the late 80s and early 90s the makeup was off and Kiss were a (no pun intended) washed up "bunch of posers."This DVD dispels the myth that Kiss were ever posers. They indeed were always great musicians and they were the inspiration for many metal bands rocking your world today (rumor has it that while backstage at a 70s Kiss show Eddie Van Halen's signature guitar tapping was inspired while seeing Ace Frehley do it). And Kiss so happen to have put on one of the most theatrical shows in rock and roll history.And that history is captured on this 2-disk DVD, albeit mostly with terrible video quality.Man, did I ever enjoy being able to see the original line-up of Kiss perform on these disks. The thing is that the awesome performances on these disks are mostly footage from 1974 - 1977 live shows, so the quality is early 70s video...and that ain't good. Often times in the live performances there are major reminders that the video is dated: horizontal lines across the picture, complete picture blackouts and just plain old low quality video.On the other hand, the audio on the first two disks is a completely different story. The audio wizards cleaned up the sound on Disks 1 & 2 and they've offered it with a terrific 5.1 Dolby mix.After enjoying what was more of a front row seat experience with the quality HD video and surround sound on the awesome, 5-star Rock the Nation 2004 DVD by Kiss, the live performances in the Kissology set were reduced to mere DVD viewings. However, it was great to reminisce and watch as Gene, Paul, Ace & Peter went through their classics of the era. And the Kissology set that I got included a 3rd bonus disk that to my surprise was a show from Madison Square Garden in February 1977 THAT I WAS AT! reviewText: Let me start off this review by saying that ever since I was in the fourth grade,I have been one of the most hardcore KISS fans on this planet. And,despite all of the sad and pathetic problems that have continued to plague KISS over the course of their career,it is great to see the release of KISS' new and most recent DVD:"KISS-KISSOLOGY-The Ultimate KISS Collection-Vol. 1-1974-1977"--something that does the job at giving justice to and proving the talent and essence of the KISS name.This set has a total of two discs in it--representing the entire 70's era of KISS--from the beginning of their career in the spotlight in 1974,to their last real success in the 70's with the "Love Gun" tour. Not only is it nice for this set to have a live performance of a known,never officially released KISS track for the Simmons/Frehley penned "Acrobat",and the music videos for "Hard Luck Woman" and "Love 'Em and Leave 'Em" (especially since most KISS home video releases from the late 80's and early 90's have 80's era KISS videos instead of 70's era KISS videos),this set also contains a total of four KISS concerts (San Fransisco's Winterland from January '75,Detroit's Cobo Hall from January '76,Tokyo's Budokan Hall from April '77,and,last but not least,Houston's The Summit from September '77). While none of these concerts stand out,they are still good concerts and well chosen offers for KISS fans. Not only is the setlist for each of the four concerts excellent and allow KISS fans who purchase/purchased this set to see various KISS classics ("Shout It Out Loud","Rock and Roll All Nite","Beth",etc.)performed live with lesser known KISS songs("Take Me","Nothin' To Lose",etc.),it makes this DVD as complete and interesting as every anthology DVD for a band needs to be. The performances show the energy that the original KISS has as a live band and allows KISS fans to witness/re-live what a 70's era KISS concert was like,with the special techniques that KISS uses in all of their shows ***AND*** the shows that are here (I'd give it away--but the shows are better to see on this DVD if the details of them are not given away),proving that KISS DO deserve all of the hype,attention,and popularity that they have achieved over all of these years.The clips from the various television shows that KISS were on in the 70's (ABC's In Concert,The Mike Douglas Show,The Midnight Special,The Paul Lynde Halloween Special,and Don Kirshner's Rock Concert)are a nice touch to this set,and allow KISS fans to learn more about KISS with this DVD set by showing the interviews that were conducted for/with KISS on these television shows (wait until you see the Gene Simmons interview on the Mike Douglas show--both cool and hillarious,as well as nostalgic!). It is a good way in letting all KISS fans (both old and new--even if you already know all about the band)know more about the history of KISS. Also,the booklet that is accompanying this set is very informative and entertaining,and feautures not only a great letter about this set and printed autograph from Paul Stanley,but also great 70's era KISS photos and background information from Gene Simmons,Paul Stanley,Ace Frehley,and Peter Criss (let me also add that it is nice to see that both Gene and Paul WERE considerate enough to let both Ace and Peter take part in this set),and will do a good job at satisfying all hardcore fans of KISS,especially with all of the beautiful photos of KISS that have been taken over the years--both previously released and previously unreleased.The only major dissapointments here are the whole issue with the so-called "bonus discs" (buying this off of Amazon or anywhere else besides Best Buy and Wal-Mart brings you the Madison Square Garden '77 show,buying this from only Best Buy brings you the Cobo Hall '76 show,and buying this at Wal-Mart brings you the Largo '77 show). While a good idea,it is pretty obvious that these bonus discs were thrown in here for Gene and Paul to make a few extra dollars. With the MSG '77 show including a very small setlist and a fuzzy screen and a Cobo Hall KISS show being included as one of the KISS concerts on disc one of this DVD,I recommend buying this wherever you can get it without the worry for a bonus disc--it is a decision you WON'T regret. Also,WHAT were Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley thinking to NOT include the live version of "Beth" that Peter Criss sang on the Paul Lynde show? That performance is what set KISS' career for the 70's,and this set missing that performance not only misses out on this set being a five star set,but also lessens the set by making the set another product of the "Gene/Paul vs. Ace/Peter" show/contest,which Gene and Paul have won every time.Overall,despite its faults,a nice set with lots of great KISS footage (good selections of footage also). It is nice to see more footage of the original KISS being released,and hopefully,the next two volumes of this set will be just as good and improve this set in the weak areas of this set.
summary: KISS fans....here is what we have been waiting for!!!!!

reviewText: Every KISS fan's dream video collection is probably a full unedited concert from every tour.  We're not quite there, but after three decades, KISS finally has a worthy video release.  Over six hours of footage on two discs plus a bonus disc (in Amazon's case, it's a seven-track Madison Square Garden disc from 1977).  None of it is new to anybody thanks to years of...uh..."tape trading"...but you'll appreciate the comparative transfer quality.  In particular, the Cadillac Michigan footage (which has a modern narration done over the phone by a local participant) is cleaner than it's ever been.The DVD auto plays out of the box but, once you hit "Menu", has a fine structure separated by decade, then feature, and if you choose a concert, by song.There's plenty of footage missing, most glaringly "Beth" from the Paul Lynde Show.  Considering Stanley even mentions Peter sitting at the keyless piano in the liner notes, you'd think they'd include it.In any case, it's here, and I'm happy to have it.  Bring on Volume 2!

reviewText: I don't know what kind of feedback I'll get from this, but this is my honest opinion. I have read most of the reviews on KISSOLOGY, and I understand that many of the bootleg tapes have better video and/or audio quality than much of the footage on this compilation. Not trying to be pious or judgemental here AT ALL, so please don't misunderstand me, but let's face it. People, you are not SUPPOSED to have bootleg videos and this stuff is brand new to fans like me.As a dyed-in-the-wool KISS fan from WAY back, I have often been envious of people (my friends included) who had bootleg footage of KISS, but I just couldn't do it myself, knowing it wasn't right. Call me a prude or whatever you like, that's just the way I felt/feel. Now that KISS has released this footage of their old shows that have been available for years in bootleg form, I have read some reviews panning the new footage as "worse than the bootleg videos" or "If you have the bootlegs, save your money on this DVD", etc (paraphrasing).Well, as a huge fan who has never bought nor seen the bootleg stuff, I am VERY pleased with this DVD! It is all new to me, and that makes it even more worth the modest price! I suppose in that respect, I have no idea what is missing or altered in this compilation, but I really don't care at all. It's GREAT to see this old, grainy footage of VINTAGE KISS in the form it is in, and I wouldn't trade this DVD for any other DVD straight up. No way!So again, please don't think me too judgemental. I really don't mean to be. If you have your bootleg videos, go ahead and enjoy them and more power to you. To each his own, I always say. God knows I often wish I had some of those old boots myself at times, but just couldn't pull the trigger. But NOW, I don't need them! This is the REAL STUFF! And I give it 5 stars. Admittedly, not EVERY aspect of this DVD deserves the 5 star treatment. Grainy video quality on the oldest shows, sub-par audio on those same shows, but hell, this is KISS as KISS was meant to be, and I LOVE it enough to give it 6 stars if I could!Happy New Year, KISS Army! Peace.
